Dates, none: that’s out of my note: Nutmegges, ſeuen;
a Race or two of Ginger, but that I may begge: Foure
pound of Prewyns, and as many of Reyſons o’th Sun.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Oh, that euer I was borne.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I’th’ name of me.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Oh helpe me, helpe mee: plucke but off theſe
ragges: and then, death, death.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Alacke poore ſoule, thou haſt need of more rags
to lay on thee, rather then haue theſe off.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Oh ſir, the loathſomneſſe of them offend mee,
more then the ſtripes I haue receiued, which are mightie
ones and millions.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Alas poore man, a million of beating may come
to a great matter.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I am rob’d ſir, and beaten: my money, and ap-
parrell tane from me, and theſe deteſtable things put vp-
on me.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: What, by a horſe-man, or a foot-man?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: A footman (ſweet ſir) a footman.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Indeed, he ſhould be a footman, by the garments
he has leﬅ with thee: If this bee a horſemans Coate, it
hath ſeene very hot ſeruice. Lend me thy hand, Ile helpe
thee. Come, lend me thy hand.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Oh good ſir, tenderly, oh.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Alas poore ſoule.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Oh good ſir, ſoﬅly, good ſir: I feare (ſir) my
ſhoulder-blade is out.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: How now? Canſt ſtand?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Soﬅly, deere ſir: good ſir, ſoﬅly: you ha done
me a charitable ofﬁce.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Dœſt lacke any mony? I haue a little mony for
thee.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: No, good ſweet ſir: no, I beſeech you ſir: I haue
a Kinſman not paſt three quarters of a mile hence, vnto
whome I was going: I ſhall there haue money, or anie
thing I want: Offer me no money I pray you, that killes
my heart.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: What manner of Fellow was hee that robb’d
you?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: A fellow (ſir) that I haue knowne to gœ about
with Troll-my-dames: I knew him once a ſeruant of the
Prince: I cannot tell good ſir, for which of his Ver-
tues it was, but hee was certainely Whipt out of the
Court.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: His vices you would ſay: there’s no vertue whipt
out of the Court: they cheriſh it to make it ſtay there;
and yet it will no more but abide.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Vices I would ſay (Sir.) I know this man well,
he hath bene ſince an Ape-bearer, then a Proceſſe-ſeruer
(a Bayliffe) then hee compaſt a Motion of the Prodigall
ſonne, and married a Tinkers wife, within a Mile where
my Land and Liuing lyes; and (hauing ﬂowne ouer ma-
ny knauiſh profeſſions) he ſetled onely in Rogue: ſome
call him Autolicus.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Out vpon him: Prig, for my life Prig: he haunts
Wakes, Faires, and Beare-baitings.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Very true ſir: he ſir hee: that’s the Rogue that
put me into this apparrell.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Not a more cowardly Rogue in all Bohemia; If
you had but look’d bigge, and ſpit at him, hee’ld haue
runne.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I muſt confeſſe to you (ſir) I am no ﬁghter: I am
falſe of heart that way, & that he knew I warrant him.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: How do you now?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Sweet ſir, much better then I was: I can ſtand,
and walke: I will euen take my leaue of you, & pace ſoﬅ-
ly towards my Kinſmans.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Shall I bring thee on the way?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: No, good fac’d ſir, no ſweet ſir.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Then fartheewell, I muſt go buy Spices for our
ſheepe-ſhearing.Exit.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Proſper you ſweet ſir. Your purſe is not hot e-
nough to purchaſe your Spice: Ile be with you at your
ſheepe-ſhearing too: If I make not this Cheat bring out
another, and the ſheerers proue ſheepe, let me be vnrold,
and my name put in the booke of Vertue.
Song. Iog-on, Iog-on, the foot-path way,
And merrily hent the Stile-a:
A merry heart gœs all the day,
Your ſad tyres in a Mile-a.Exit.

scene.stagedir: Enter Florizell, Perdita, Shepherd, Clowne, Polixenes, Camillo, Mopſa, Dorcas, Seruants, Autolicus.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Theſe your vnvſuall weeds, to each part of you
Do’s giue a life: no Shepherdeſſe, but Flora
Peering in Aprils front. This your ſheepe-ſhearing,
Is as a meeting of the petty Gods,
And you the Queene on’t.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Sir: my gracious Lord,
To chide at your extreames, it not becomes me:
(Oh pardon, that I name them:) your high ſelfe
The gracious marke o’th’ Land, you haue obſcur’d
With a Swaines wearing: and me (poore lowly Maide)
Moſt Goddeſſe-like prank’d vp: But that our Feaſts
In euery Meſſe, haue folly; and the Feeders
Digeſt with a Cuſtome, I ſhould bluſh
To ſee you ſo attyr’d: ſworne I thinke,
To ſhew my ſelfe a glaſſe.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: I bleſſe the time
When my good Falcon, made her ﬂight a-croſſe
Thy Fathers ground.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Now Ioue affoord you cauſe:
To me the difference forges dread (your Greatneſſe
Hath not beene vs’d to feare:) euen now I tremble
To thinke your Father, by ſome accident
Should paſſe this way, as you did: Oh the Fates,
How would he looke, to ſee his worke, ſo noble,
Vildely bound vp? What would he ſay? Or how
Should I (in theſe my borrowed Flaunts) behold
The ſternneſſe of his preſence?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Apprehend
Nothing but iollity: the Goddes themſelues
(Humbling their Deities to loue) haue taken
The ſhapes of Beaſts vpon them. Iupiter,
Became a Bull, and bellow’d: the greene Neptune
A Ram, and bleated: and the Fire-roab’d-God
Golden Apollo, a poore humble Swaine,
As I ſeeme now. Their transformations,
Were neuer for a peece of beauty, rarer,
Nor in a way ſo chaſte: ſince my deſires
Run not before mine honor: nor my Luſts
Burne hotter then my Faith.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: O but Sir,
Your reſolution cannot hold, when ’tis
Oppos’d (as it muſt be) by th’ powre of the King:
One of theſe two muſt be neceſsities,
Which then will ſpeake, that you muſt change this purpoſe,
Or I my life.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Thou deer’ſt Perdita,
With theſe forc’d thoughts, I prethee darken not
The Mirth o’th’ Feaſt: Or Ile be thine (my Faire)
Or not my Fathers. For I cannot be
Mine owne, nor any thing to any, if
I be not thine. To this I am moſt conſtant,
Though deſtiny ſay no. Be merry (Gentle)
Strangle ſuch thoughts as theſe, with any thing
That you behold the while. Your gueſts are comming:
Liﬅ vp your countenance, as it were the day
Of celebration of that nuptiall, which
We two haue ſworne ſhall come.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: O Lady Fortune,
Stand you auſpicious.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: See, your Gueſts approach,
Addreſſe your ſelfe to entertaine them ſprightly,
And let’s be red with mirth.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Fy (daughter) when my old wife liu’d: vpon
This day, ſhe was both Pantler, Butler, Cooke,
Both Dame and Seruant: Welcom’d all: ſeru’d all,
Would ſing her ſong, and dance her turne: now heere
At vpper end o’th Table; now, i’th middle:
On his ſhoulder, and his: her face o’ ﬁre
With labour, and the thing ſhe tooke to quench it
She would to each one ſip. You are retyred,
As if you were a feaſted one: and not
The Hoſteſſe of the meeting: Pray you bid
Theſe vnknowne friends to’s welcome, for it is
A way to make vs better Friends, more knowne.
Come, quench your bluſhes, and preſent your ſelfe
That which you are, Miſtris o’th’ Feaſt. Come on,
And bid vs welcome to your ſheepe-ſhearing,
As your good ﬂocke ſhall proſper.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Sir, welcome:
It is my Fathers will, I ſhould take on mee
The Hoſteſſeſhip o’th’ day: you’re welcome ſir.
Giue me thoſe Flowres there (Dorcas.) Reuerend Sirs,
For you, there’s Rosemary, and Rue, these keepe
Seeming, and ſauour all the Winter long:
Grace, and Remembrance be to you both,
And welcome to our Shearing.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Shepherdeſſe,
(A faire one are you:) well you ﬁt our ages
With ﬂowres of Winter.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Sir, the yeare growing ancient,
Not yet on ſummers death, nor on the birth
Of trembling winter, the fayreſt ﬂowres o’th ſeaſon
Are our Carnations, and ſtreak’d Gilly-vors,
(Which ſome call Natures baſtards) of that kind
Our ruſticke Gardens barren, and I care not
To get ſlips of them.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Wherefore (gentle Maiden)
Do you negleƈt them.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: For I haue heard it ſaid,
There is an Art, which in their pideneſſe ſhares
With great creating-Nature.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Say there be:
Yet Nature is made better by no meane,
But Nature makes that Meane: ſo ouer that Art,
(Which you ſay addes to Nature) is an Art
That Nature makes: you ſee (ſweet Maid) we marry
A gentler Sien, to the wildeſt Stocke,
And make conceyue a barke of baſer kinde
By bud of Nobler race. This is an Art
Which do’s mend Nature: change it rather, but
The Art it ſelfe, is Nature.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: So it is.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Then make you Garden rich in Gilly’ vors,
And do not call them baſtards.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Ile not put
The Dible in earth, to ſet one ſlip of them:
No more then were I painted, I would wiſh
This youth ſhould ſay ’twer well: and onely therefore
Deſire to breed by me. Here’s flowres for you:
Hot Lauender, Mints, Sauory, Mariorum,
The Mary-gold, that goes to bed with’ Sun,
And with him rises, weeping: These are ﬂowres
Of middle ſummer, and I thinke they are giuen
To men of middle age. Y’are very welcome.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: I ſhould leaue graſing, were I of your ﬂocke,
And onely liue by gazing.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Out alas:
You’ld be ſo leane, that blaſts of Ianuary
Would blow you through and through. Now (my fairſt Friend,
I would I had ſome Flowres o’th Spring, that might
Become your time of day: and yours, and yours,
That weare vpon your Virgin-branches yet
Your Maiden-heads growing: O Proſerpina,
For the Flowres now, that (frighted) thou let’ſt fall
From Dyſſes Waggon: Daffadils,
That come before the Swallow dares, and take
The windes of March with beauty: Violets (dim,
But ſweeter then the lids of Iuno’s eyes,
Or Cytherea’s breath) pale Prime-roſes,
That dye vnmarried, ere they can behold
Bright Phœbus in his ſtrength (a Maladie
Moſt incident to Maids:) bold Oxlips, and
The Crowne Imperiall: Lillies of all kinds,
(The Flowre-de-Luce being one.) O, theſe I lacke,
To make you Garlands of) and my ſweet friend,
To ſtrew him o’re, and ore.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: What? like a Coarſe?

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: No, like a banke, for Loue to lye, and play on:
Not like a Coarſe: or if: not to be buried,
But quicke, and in mine armes. Come, take your ﬂours,
Me thinkes I play as I haue ſeene them do
In Whitſon-Paſtorals: Sure this Robe of mine
Do’s change my diſpoſition:

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: What you do,
Still betters what is done. When you ſpeake (Sweet)
I’ld haue you do it euer: When you ſing,
I’ld haue you buy, and ſell ſo: ſo giue Almes,
Pray ſo: and for the ord’ring your Affayres,
To ſing them too. When you do dance, I wiſh you
A waue o’th Sea, that you might euer do
Nothing but that: moue ſtill, ſtill ſo:
And owne no other Funƈtion. Each your doing,
(So ſingular, in each particular)
Crownes what you are doing, in the preſent deeds,
That all your Aƈtes, are Queenes.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: O Doricles,
Your praiſes are too large: but that your youth
And the true blood which peepes fairely through’t,
Do plainly giue you out an vnſtain’d Sphepherd
With wiſedome, I might feare (my Doricles)
You woo’d me the falſe way.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: I thinke you haue
As little skill to feare, as I haue purpoſe
To put you to’t. But come, our dance I pray,
Your hand (my Perdita:) ſo Turtles paire
That neuer meane to part.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Ile ſweare for ’em.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: This is the prettieſt Low-borne Laſſe, that euer
Ran on the greene-ſord: Nothing ſhe do’s, or ſeemes
But ſmackes of ſomething greater then her ſelfe,
Too Noble for this place.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: He tels her ſomething
That makes her blood looke on’t: Good ſooth ſhe is
The Queene of Curds and Creame.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Come on: ſtrike vp.

speech.speaker: Dorcas.
speech.line: Mopſa muſt be your Miſtris: marry Garlick
to mend her kiſſing with.

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: Now in good time.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Not a word, a word, we ſtand vpon our manners,
Come, ſtrike vp.

scene.stagedir: Heere a Daunce of Shepheards and Shephearddeſſes.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Pray good Shepheard, what faire Swaine is this,
Which dances with your daughter?

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: They call him Doricles, and boaſts himſelfe
To haue a worthy Feeding; but I haue it
Vpon his owne report, and I beleeue it:
He lookes like ſooth: he ſayes he loues my daughter,
I thinke ſo too; for neuer gaz’d the Moone
Vpon the water, as hee’l ſtand and reade
As ’twere my daughters eyes: and to be plaine,
I thinke there is not halfe a kiſſe to chooſe
Who loues another beſt.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: She dances featly.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: So ſhe do’s any thing, though I report it
That ſhould be ſilent: If yong Doricles
Do light vpon her, ſhe ſhall bring him that
Which he not dreames of.Enter Seruant.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: O Maſter: if you did but heare the Pedler at the
doore, you would neuer dance againe aﬅer a Tabor and
Pipe: no, the Bag-pipe could not moue you: hee ſinges
ſeuerall Tunes, faſter then you’l tell money: hee vtters
them as he had eaten ballads, and all mens eares grew to
his Tunes.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: He could neuer come better: hee ſhall come in:
I loue a ballad but euen too well, if it be dolefull matter
merrily ſet downe: or a very pleaſant thing indeede, and
ſung lamentably.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: He hath ſongs for man, or woman, of all ſizes:
No Milliner can ſo ﬁt his cuſtomers with Gloues: he has
the prettieſt Loue-ſongs for Maids, ſo without bawdrie
(which is ſtrange,) with ſuch delicate burthens of Dil-
do’s and Fadings: Iump-her, and thump-her; and where
ſome ſtretch-mouth’d Raſcall, would (as it were) meane
miſcheefe, and breake a fowle gap into the Matter, hee
makes the maid to anſwere, Whoop, dœ me no harme good
man: put’s him off, ſlights him, with Whoop, dœ mee no
harme good man.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: This is a braue fellow.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Beleeue mee, thou talkeſt of an admirable con-
ceited fellow, has he any vnbraided Wares?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Hee hath Ribbons of all the colours i’th Raine-
bow; Points, more then all the Lawyers in Bohemia, can
learnedly handle, though they come to him by th’ groſſe:
Inckles, Caddyſſes, Cambrickes, Lawnes: why he ſings
em ouer, as they were Gods, or Goddeſſes: you would
thinke a Smocke were a ſhee-Angell, he ſo chauntes to
the ſleeue-hand, and the worke about the ſquare on’t.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Pre’thee bring him in, and let him approach ſin-
ging.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Forewarne him, that he vſe no ſcurrilous words
in’s tunes.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: You haue of theſe Pedlers, that haue more in
them, then youl’d thinke (Siſter.)

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: I, good brother, or go about to thinke.
Lawne as white as driuen Snow,
Cypreſſe blacke as ere was Crow,
Gloues as ſweete as Damaske Roſes,
Maskes for faces, and for noſes:
Bugle-bracelet, Necke-lace Amber,
Perfume for a Ladies Chamber:
Golden Quoifes, and Stomachers
For my Lads, to giue their deers:
Pins, and poaking-ſtickes of ſteele.
What Maids lacke from head to heele:
Come buy of me, come: come buy, come buy,
Buy Lads, or elſe your Laſſes cry: Come buy.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: If I were not in loue with Mopſa, thou ſhouldſt
take no money of me, but being enthrall’d as I am, it will
alſo be the bondage of certaine Ribbons and Gloues.

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: I was promis’d them againſt the Feaſt, but they
come not too late now.

speech.speaker: Dor.
speech.line: He hath promis’d you more then that, or there
be lyars.

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: He hath paid you all he promis’d you: ’May be
he has paid you more, which will ſhame you to giue him
againe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Is there no manners leﬅ among maids? Will they
weare their plackets, where they ſhould bear their faces?
Is there not milking-time? When you are going to bed?
Or kill-hole? To whiſtle of theſe ſecrets, but you muſt
be tittle-tatling before all our gueſts? ’Tis well they are
whiſpring: clamor your tongues, and not a word more.

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: I haue done; Come you promis’d me a tawdry-
lace, and a paire of ſweet Gloues.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Haue I not told thee how I was cozen’d by the
way, and loſt all my money.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: And indeed Sir, there are Cozeners abroad, ther-
fore it behooues men to be wary.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Feare not thou man, thou ſhalt loſe nothing here

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I hope ſo ſir, for I haue about me many parcels
of charge.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: What haſt heere? Ballads?

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: Pray now buy ſome: I loue a ballet in print, a
life, for then we are ſure they are true.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Here’s one, to a very dolefull tune, how a Vſu-
rers wife was brought to bed of twenty money baggs at
a burthen, and how ſhe long’d to eate Adders heads, and
Toads carbonado’d.

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: Is it true, thinke you?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Very true, and but a moneth old.

speech.speaker: Dor.
speech.line: Bleſſe me from marrying a Vſurer.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Here’s the Midwiues name to’t: one Miſt. Tale-
Porter, and ﬁue or ſix honeſt Wiues, that were preſent.
Why ſhould I carry lyes abroad?

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: ’Pray you now buy it.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Come-on, lay it by: and let’s ﬁrſt ſee mœ Bal-
lads: Wee’l buy the other things anon.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Here’s another ballad of a Fiſh, that appeared
vpon the coaſt, on wenſday the foureſcore of April, fortie
thouſand fadom aboue water, & ſung this ballad againſt
the hard hearts of maids: it was thought ſhe was a Wo-
man, and was turn’d into a cold ﬁſh, for ſhe wold not ex-
change ﬂeſh with one that lou’d her: The Ballad is very
pittifull, and as true.

speech.speaker: Dor.
speech.line: Is it true too, thinke you.

speech.speaker: Autol.
speech.line: Fiue Iuſtices hands at it, and witneſſes more
then my packe will hold.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Lay it by too; another.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: This is a merry ballad, but a very pretty one.

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: Let’s haue ſome merry ones.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Why this is a paſſing merry one, and gœs to the
tune of two maids wooing a man: there’s ſcarſe a Maide
weſtward but ſhe ſings it: ’tis in requeſt, I can tell you.

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: We can both ſing it: if thou’lt beare a part, thou
ſhalt heare, ’tis in three parts.

speech.speaker: Dor.
speech.line: We had the tune on’t, a month agœ.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I can beare my part, you muſt know ’tis my oc-
cupation: Haue at it with you:
Get you hence, for I muſt gœ

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Where it ﬁts not you to know.

speech.speaker: Dor.
speech.line: Whether?

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: O whether?

speech.speaker: Dor.
speech.line: Whether?

speech.speaker: Mop.
speech.line: It becomes thy oath full well,
Thou to me thy ſecrets tell.
speech.speaker: Dor:
speech.line: Me too: Let me go thether:
speech.speaker: Mop:
speech.line: Or thou gœſt to th’ Grange, or Mill,
speech.speaker: Dor:
speech.line: If to either thou doſt ill,
speech.speaker: Aut:
speech.line: Neither.
speech.speaker: Dor:
speech.line: What neither?
speech.speaker: Aut:
speech.line: Neither:
speech.speaker: Dor:
speech.line: Thou haſt ſworne my Loue to be,
speech.speaker: Mop:
speech.line: Thou haſt ſworne it more to mee.
Then whether gœſt? Say whether?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Wee’l haue this ſong out anon by our ſelues: My
Father, and the Gent. are in ſad talke, & wee’ll not trouble
them: Come bring away thy pack aﬅer me, Wenches Ile
buy for you both: Pedler let’s haue the ﬁrſt choice; folow
me girles.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: And you ſhall pay well for ’em.
Song.Will you buy any Tape, or Lace for your Cape?
My dainty Ducke, my deere-a?
Any Silke, any Thred, any Toyes for your head
Of the news’t, and ﬁns’t, ﬁns’t weare-a.
Come to the Pedler, Money’s a medler,
That doth vtter all mens ware-a.Exit

speech.speaker: Seruant.
speech.line: Mayſter, there is three Carters, three Shep-
herds, three Neat-herds, three Swine-herds ý haue made
themſelues all men of haire, they cal themſelues Saltiers,
and they haue a Dance, which the Wenches ſay is a gal-
ly-maufrey of Gambols, becauſe they are not in’t: but
they themſelues are o’th’ minde (if it bee not too rough
for ſome, that know little but bowling) it will pleaſe
plentifully.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Away: Wee’l none on’t; heere has beene too
much homely foolery already. I know (Sir) wee wea-
rie you.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: You wearie thoſe that refreſh vs: pray let’s ſee
theſe foure-threes of Heardſmen.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: One three of them, by their owne report (Sir,)
hath danc’d before the King: and not the worſt of the
three, but iumpes twelue foote and a halfe by th’ ſquire.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Leaue your prating, ſince theſe good men are
pleaſ’d, let them come in: but quickly now.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Why, they ſtay at doore Sir.

scene.stagedir: Heere a Dance of twelue Satyres.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: O Father, you’l know more of that heereaﬅer:
Is it not too farre gone? ’Tis time to part them,
He’s ſimple, and tels much. How now (faire ſhepheard)
Your heart is full of ſomething, that do’s take
Your minde from feaſting. Sooth, when I was yong,
And handed loue, as you do; I was wont
To load my Shee with knackes: I would haue ranſackt
The Pedlers ſilken Treaſury, and haue powr’d it
To her acceptance: you haue let him go,
And nothing marted with him. If your Laſſe
Interpretation ſhould abuſe, and call this
Your lacke of loue, or bounty, you were ſtraited
For a reply at leaſt, if you make a care
Of happie holding her.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Old Sir, I know
She prizes not ſuch triﬂes as theſe are:
The giﬅs ſhe lookes from me, are packt and lockt
Vp in my heart, which I haue giuen already,
But not deliuer’d. O heare me breath my life
Before this ancient Sir, whom (it ſhould ſeeme)
Hath ſometime lou’d: I take thy hand, this hand,
As ſoﬅ as Doues-downe, and as white as it,
Or Ethyopians tooth, or the fan’d ſnow, that’s bolted
By th’ Northerne blaſts, twice ore.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: What followes this?
How prettily th’ yong Swaine ſeemes to waſh
The hand, was faire before? I haue put you out,
But to your proteſtation: Let me heare
What you profeſſe.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Do, and be witneſſe too’t.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: And this my neighbour too?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: And he, and more
Then he, and men: the earth, the heauens, and all;
That were I crown’d the moſt Imperiall Monarch
Thereof moſt worthy: were I the fayreſt youth
That euer made eye ſwerue, had force and knowledge
More then was euer mans, I would not prize them
Without her Loue; for her, employ them all,
Commend them, and condemne them to her ſeruice,
Or to their owne perdition.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Fairely offer’d.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: This ſhewes a ſound affeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: But my daughter,
Say you the like to him.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: I cannot ſpeake
So well, (nothing ſo well) no, nor meane better
By th’ patterne of mine owne thoughts, I cut out
The puritie of his.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Take hands, a bargaine;
And friends vnknowne, you ſhall beare witneſſe to’t:
I giue my daughter to him, and will make
Her Portion, equall his.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: O, that muſt bee
I’th Vertue of your daughter: One being dead,
I ſhall haue more then you can dreame of yet,
Enough then for your wonder: but come-on,
Contraƈt vs fore theſe Witneſſes.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Come, your hand:
And daughter, yours.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Soﬅ Swaine a-while, beſeech you,
Haue you a Father?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: I haue: but what of him?

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Knowes he of this?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: He neither do’s, nor ſhall.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Me-thinkes a Father,
Is at the Nuptiall of his ſonne, a gueſt
That beſt becomes the Table: Pray you once more
Is not your Father growne incapeable
Of reaſonable affayres? Is he not ſtupid
With Age, and altring Rheumes? Can he ſpeake? heare?
Know man, from man? Diſpute his owne eſtate?
Lies he not bed-rid? And againe, do’s nothing
But what he did, being childiſh?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: No good Sir:
He has his health, and ampler ſtrength indeede
Then moſt haue of his age.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: By my white beard,
You offer him (if this be ſo) a wrong
Something vnﬁlliall: Reaſon my ſonne
Should chooſe himſelfe a wife, but as good reaſon
The Father (all whoſe ioy is nothing elſe
But faire poſterity) ſhould hold ſome counſaile
In ſuch a buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: I yeeld all this;
But for ſome other reaſons (my graue Sir)
Which ’tis not ﬁt you know, I not acquaint
My Father of this buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Let him know’t.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: He ſhall not.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Prethee let him.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: No, he muſt not.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Let him (my ſonne) he ſhall not need to greeue
At knowing of thy choice.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Come, come, he muſt not:
Marke our Contraƈt.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Marke your diuorce (yong ſir)
Whom ſonne I dare not call: Thou art too baſe
To be acknowledge. Thou a Scepters heire,
That thus affeƈts a ſheepe-hooke? Thou, old Traitor,
I am ſorry, that by hanging thee, I can
But ſhorten thy life one weeke. And thou, freſh peece
Of excellent Witchcraﬅ, whom of force muſt know
The royall Foole thou coap’ſt with.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Oh my heart.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Ile haue thy beauty ſcratcht with briers & made
More homely then thy ſtate. For thee (fond boy)
If I may euer know thou doſt but ſigh,
That thou no more ſhalt neuer ſee this knacke (as neuer
I meane thou ſhalt) wee’l barre thee from ſucceſſion,
Not hold thee of our blood, no not our Kin,
Farre then Deucalion off: (marke thou my words)
Follow vs to the Court. Thou Churle, for this time
(Though full of our diſpleaſure) yet we free thee
From the dead blow of it. And you Enchantment,
Worthy enough a Heardſman: yea him too,
That makes himſelfe (but for our Honor therein)
Vnworthy thee. If euer henceforth, thou
Theſe rurall Latches, to his entrance open,
Or hope his body more, with thy embraces,
I will deuiſe a death, as cruell for thee
As thou art tender to’t.Exit.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Euen heere vndone:
I was not much a-fear’d: for once, or twice
I was about to ſpeake, and tell him plainely,
The ſelfe-ſame Sun, that ſhines vpon his Court,
Hides not his viſage from our Cottage, but
Lookes on alike. Wilt pleaſe you (Sir) be gone?
I told you what would come of this: Beſeech you
Of your owne ſtate take care: This dreame of mine
Being now awake, Ile Queene it no inch farther,
But milke my Ewes, and weepe.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Why how now Father,
Speake ere thou dyeſt.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: I cannot ſpeake, nor thinke,
Nor dare to know, that which I know: O Sir,
You haue vndone a man of foureſcore three,
That thought to ﬁll his graue in quiet: yea,
To dye vpon the bed my father dy’de,
To lye cloſe by his honeſt bones; but now
Some Hangman muſt put on my ſhrowd, and lay me
Where no Prieſt ſhouels-in duſt. Oh curſed wretch,
That knew’ſt this was the Prince, and wouldſt aduenture
To mingle faith with him. Vndone, vndone:
If I might dye within this houre, I haue liu’d
To die when I deſire.Exit.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Why looke you ſo vpon me?
I am but ſorry, not affear’d: delaid,
But nothing altred: What I was, I am:
More ſtraining on, for plucking backe; not following
My leaſh vnwillingly.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Gracious my Lord,
You know my Fathers temper: at this time
He will allow no ſpeech: (which I do gheſſe
You do not purpoſe to him:) and as hardly
Will he endure your ſight, as yet I feare;
Then till the fury of his Highneſſe ſettle
Come not before him.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: I not purpoſe it:
I thinke Camillo.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Euen he, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Per.
speech.line: How oﬅen haue I told you ’twould be thus?
How oﬅen ſaid my dignity would laſt
But till ’twer knowne?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: It cannot faile, but by
The violation of my faith, and then
Let Nature cruſh the ſides o’th earth together,
And marre the ſeeds within. Liﬅ vp thy lookes:
From my ſucceſſion wipe me (Father) I
Am heyre to my affeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Be aduis’d.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: I am: and by my fancie, if my Reaſon
Will thereto be obedient: I haue reaſon:
If not, my ſences better pleas’d with madneſſe,
Do bid it welcome.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: This is deſperate (ſir.)

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: So call it: but it do’s fulﬁll my vow:
I needs muſt thinke it honeſty. Camillo,
Not for Bohemia, nor the pompe that may
Be thereat gleaned: for all the Sun ſees, or
The cloſe earth wombes, or the profound ſeas, hides
In vnknowne fadomes, will I breake my oath
To this my faire belou’d: Therefore, I pray you,
As you haue euer bin my Fathers honour’d friend,
When he ſhall miſſe me, as (in faith I meane not
To ſee him any more) caſt your good counſailes
Vpon his paſsion: Let my ſelfe, and Fortune
Tug for the time to come. This you may know,
And ſo deliuer, I am put to Sea
With her, who heere I cannot hold on ſhore:
And moſt opportune to her neede, I haue
A Veſſell rides faſt by, but not prepar’d
For this deſigne. What courſe I meane to hold
Shall nothing beneﬁt your knowledge, nor
Concerne me the reporting.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: O my Lord,
I would your ſpirit were eaſier for aduice,
Or ſtronger for your neede.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Hearke Perdita,
Ile heare you by and by.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Hee’s irremoueable,
Reſolu’d for flight: Now were I happy if
His going, I could frame to ſerue my turne,
Saue him from danger, do him loue and honor,
Purchaſe the ſight againe of deere Sicillia,
And that vnhappy King, my Maſter, whom
I ſo much thirſt to ſee.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Now good Camillo,
I am ſo fraught with curious buſineſſe, that
I leaue out ceremony.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Sir, I thinke
You haue heard of my poore ſeruices, i’th loue
That I haue borne your Father?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Very nobly
Haue you deſeru’d: It is my Fathers Muſicke
To ſpeake your deeds: not little of his care
To haue them recompenc’d, as thought on.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Well (my Lord)
If you may pleaſe to thinke I loue the King,
And through him, what’s neereſt to him, which is
Your gracious ſelfe; embrace but my direƈtion,
If your more ponderous and ſetled proieƈt
May ſuffer alteration. On mine honor,
Ile point you where you ſhall haue ſuch receiuing
As ſhall become your Highneſſe, where you may
Enioy your Miſtris; from the whom, I ſee
There’s no diſiunƈtion to be made, but by
(As heauens forefend) your ruine: Marry her,
And with my beſt endeuours, in your abſence,
Your diſcontenting Father, ſtriue to qualiﬁe
And bring him vp to liking.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: How Camillo
May this (almoſt a miracle) be done?
That I may call thee ſomething more then man,
And aﬅer that truſt to thee.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Haue you thought on
A place whereto you’l go?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Not any yet:
But as th’ vnthought-on accident is guiltie
To what we wildely do, ſo we profeſſe
Our ſelues to be the ſlaues of chance, and ﬂyes
Of euery winde that blowes.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Then liﬅ to me:
This followes, if you will not change your purpoſe
But vndergo this ﬂight: make for Sicillia,
And there preſent your ſelfe, and your fayre Princeſſe,
(For ſo I ſee ſhe muſt be) ’fore Leontes;
She ſhall be habited, as it becomes
The partner of your Bed. Me thinkes I ſee
Leontes opening his free Armes, and weeping
His Welcomes forth: asks thee there Sonne forgiueneſſe,
As ’twere i’th’ Fathers perſon: kiſſes the hands
Of your freſh Princeſſe; ore and ore diuides him,
’Twixt his vnkindneſſe, and his Kindneſſe: th’ one
He chides to Hell, and bids the other grow
Faſter then Thought, or Time.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Worthy Camillo,
What colour for my Viſitation, ſhall I
Hold vp before him?

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Sent by the King your Father
To greet him, and to giue him comforts. Sir,
The manner of your bearing towards him, with
What you (as from your Father) ſhall deliuer,
Things knowne betwixt vs three, Ile write you downe,
The which ſhall point you forth at euery ſitting
What you muſt ſay: that he ſhall not perceiue,
But that you haue your Fathers Boſome there,
And ſpeake his very Heart.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: I am bound to you:
There is ſome ſappe in this.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: A Courſe more promiſing,
Then a wild dedication of your ſelues
To vnpath’d Waters, vndream’d Shores; moſt certaine,
To Miſeries enough: no hope to helpe you,
But as you ſhake off one, to take another:
Nothing ſo certaine, as your Anchors, who
Dœ their beſt ofﬁce, if they can but ſtay you,
Where you’le be loth to be: beſides you know,
Proſperitie’s the very bond of Loue,
Whoſe freſh complexion, and whoſe heart together,
Afﬂiƈtion alters.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: One of theſe is true:
I thinke Afﬂiƈtion may ſubdue the Cheeke,
But not take-in the Mind.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Yea? ſay you ſo?
There ſhall not, at your Fathers Houſe, theſe ſeuen yeeres
Be borne another ſuch.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: My good Camillo,
She’s as forward, of her Breeding, as
She is i’th’ reare’ our Birth.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: I cannot ſay, ’tis pitty
She lacks Inſtruƈtions, for ſhe ſeemes a Miſtreſſe
To moſt that teach.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Your pardon Sir, for this,
Ile bluſh you Thanks.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: My prettieſt Perdita.
But O, the Thornes we ſtand vpon: (Camillo)
Preſeruer of my Father, now of me,
The Medicine of our Houſe: how ſhall we dœ?
We are not furniſh’d like Bohemia’s Sonne,
Nor ſhall appeare in Sicilia.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: My Lord,
Feare none of this: I thinke you know my fortunes
Dœ all lye there: it ſhall be ſo my care,
To haue you royally appointed, as if
The Scene you play, were mine. For inſtance Sir,
That you may know you ſhall not want: one word.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Ha, ha, what a Foole Honeſtie is? and Truſt (his
ſworne brother) a very ſimple Gentleman. I haue ſold
all my Tromperie: not a counterfeit Stone, not a Ribbon,
Glaſſe, Pomander, Browch, Table-booke, Ballad, Knife,
Tape, Gloue, Shoœ-tye, Bracelet, Horne-Ring, to keepe
my Pack from faſting: they throng who ſhould buy ﬁrſt,
as if my Trinkets had beene hallowed, and brought a be-
nediƈtion to the buyer: by which meanes, I ſaw whoſe
Purſe was beſt in Piƈture; and what I ſaw, to my good
vſe, I remembred. My Clowne (who wants but ſome-
thing to be a reaſonable man) grew ſo in loue with the
Wenches Song, that hee would not ſtirre his Petty-tœs,
till he had both Tune and Words, which ſo drew the reſt
of the Heard to me, that all their other Sences ſtucke in
Eares: you might haue pinch’d a Placket, it was ſence-
leſſe; ’twas nothing to gueld a Cod-peece of a Purſe: I
would haue ﬁll’d Keyes of that hung in Chaynes: no
hearing, no feeling, but my Sirs Song, and admiring the
Nothing of it. So that in this time of Lethargie, I pickd
and cut moſt of their Feſtiuall Purſes: And had not the
old-man come in with a Whoo-bub againſt his Daugh-
ter, and the Kings Sonne, and ſcar’d my Chowghes from
the Chaffe, I had not leﬅ a Purſe aliue in the whole
Army.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Nay, but my Letters by this meanes being there
So ſoone as you arriue, ſhall cleare that doubt.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: And thoſe that you’le procure from King Leontes?

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Shall ſatisﬁe your Father.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Happy be you:
All that you ſpeake, ſhewes faire.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Who haue we here?
Wee’le make an Inſtrument of this: omit
Nothing may giue vs aide.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: If they haue ouer-heard me now: why hanging.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: How now (good Fellow)
Why ſhak’ſt thou ſo? Feare not (man)
Here’s no harme intended to thee.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I am a poore Fellow, Sir.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Why, be ſo ſtill: here’s no body will ſteale that
from thee: yet for the out-ſide of thy pouertie, we muſt
make an exchange; therefore diſ-caſe thee inſtantly (thou
muſt thinke there’s a neceſſitie in’t) and change Garments
with this Gentleman: Though the penny-worth (on his
ſide) be the worſt, yet hold thee, there’s ſome boot.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I am a poore Fellow, Sir: (I know ye well
enough.)

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Nay prethee diſpatch: the Gentleman is halfe
ﬂed already.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Are you in earneſt, Sir? (I ſmell the trick on’t.)

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Diſpatch, I prethee.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Indeed I haue had Earneſt, but I cannot with
conſcience take it.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Vnbuckle, vnbuckle.
Fortunate Miſtreſſe (let my prophecie
Come home to ye:) you muſt retire your ſelfe
Into ſome Couert; take your ſweet-hearts Hat
And pluck it ore your Browes, mufﬂe your face,
Diſ-mantle you, and (as you can) diſliken
The truth of your owne ſeeming, that you may
(For I dœ feare eyes ouer) to Ship-boord
Get vndeſcry’d.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: I ſee the Play ſo lyes,
That I muſt beare a part.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: No remedie:
Haue you done there?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Should I now meet my Father,
He would not call me Sonne.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Nay, you ſhall haue no Hat:
Come Lady, come: Farewell (my friend.)

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Adieu, Sir.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: O Perdita: what haue we twaine forgot?
’Pray you a word.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: What I dœ next, ſhall be to tell the King
Of this eſcape, and whither they are bound;
Wherein, my hope is, I ſhall ſo preuaile,
To force him aﬅer: in whoſe company
I ſhall re-view Sicilia; for whoſe ſight,
I haue a Womans Longing.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Fortune ſpeed vs:
Thus we ſet on (Camillo) to th’ Sea-ſide.

speech.speaker: Cam
speech.line: The ſwiﬅer ſpeed, the better.Exit.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I vnderſtand the buſineſſe, I heare it: to haue an
open eare, a quick eye, and a nimble hand, is neceſſary for
a Cut-purſe; a good Noſe is requiſite alſo, to ſmell out
worke for th’ other Sences. I ſee this is the time that the
vniuſt man doth thriue. What an exchange had this been,
without boot? What a boot is here, with this exchange?
Sure the Gods dœ this yeere conniue at vs, and we may
dœ any thing extempore. The Prince himſelfe is about
a peece of Iniquitie (ſtealing away from his Father, with
his Clog at his heeles:) if I thought it were a peece of ho-
neſtie to acquaint the King withall, I would not do’t: I
hold it the more knauerie to conceale it; and therein am
I conſtant to my Profeſſion.

scene.line: Aſide, aſide, here is more matter for a hot braine: Euery
Lanes end, euery Shop, Church, Seſſion, Hanging, yeelds

speech.speaker: Clowne.
speech.line: See, ſee: what a man you are now? there is no
other way, but to tell the King ſhe’s a Changeling, and
none of your ﬂeſh and blood.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Nay, but heare me.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Nay; but heare me.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Gœ too then.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: She being none of your ﬂeſh and blood, your
ﬂeſh and blood ha’s not offended the King, and ſo your
ﬂeſh and blood is not to be puniſh’d by him. Shew thoſe
things you found about her (thoſe ſecret things, all but
what ſhe ha’s with her:) This being done, let the Law gœ
whiſtle: I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: I will tell the King all, euery word, yea, and his
Sonnes prancks too; who, I may ſay, is no honeſt man,
neither to his Father, nor to me, to gœ about to make me
the Kings Brother in Law.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Indeed Brother in Law was the fartheſt off you
could haue beene to him, and then your Blood had beene
the dearer, by I know how much an ounce.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Very wiſely (Puppies.)

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Well: let vs to the King: there is that in this
Farthell, will make him ſcratch his Beard.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I know not what impediment this Complaint
may be to the ﬂight of my Maſter.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: ’Pray heartily he be at’ Pallace.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Though I am not naturally honeſt, I am ſo ſome-
times by chance: Let me pocket vp my Pedlers excre-
ment. How now (Ruſtiques) whither are you bound?

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: To th’ Pallace ( and it like your Worſhip.)

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Your Affaires there? what? with whom? the
Condition of that Farthell? the place of your dwelling?
your names? your ages? of what hauing? breeding, and
any thing that is ﬁtting to be knowne, diſcouer?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: We are but plaine fellowes, Sir.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: A Lye; you are rough, and hayrie: Let me haue
no lying; it becomes none but Tradeſ-men, and they of-
ten giue vs (Souldiers) the Lye, but wee pay them for it
with ſtamped Coyne, not ſtabbing Steele, therefore they
dœ not giue vs the Lye.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Your Worſhip had like to haue giuen vs one, if
you had not taken your ſelfe with the manner.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Are you a Courtier, and’t like you Sir?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Whether it like me, or no, I am a Courtier. Seeſt
thou not the ayre of the Court, in theſe enfoldings? Hath
not my gate in it, the meaſure of the Court? Receiues not
thy Noſe Court-Odour from me? Reﬂeƈt I not on thy
Baſeneſſe, Court-Contempt? Think’ſt thou, for that I
inſinuate, at toaze from thee thy Buſineſſe, I am there-
fore no Courtier? I am Courtier Cap-a-pe; and one that
will eyther puſh-on, or pluck-back, thy Buſineſſe there:
whereupon I command thee to open thy Affaire.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: My Buſineſſe, Sir, is to the King.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: What Aduocate ha’ſt thou to him?

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: I know not (and’t like you.)

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Aduocate’s the Court-word for a Pheazant: ſay
you haue none.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: None, Sir: I haue no Pheazant Cock, nor Hen.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: How bleſſed are we, that are not ſimple men?
Yet Nature might haue made me as theſe are,
Therefore I will not diſdaine.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: This cannot be but a great Courtier.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: His Garments are rich, but he weares them not
handſomely.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: He ſeemes to be the more Noble, in being fanta-
ſticall: A great man, Ile warrant; I know by the picking
on’s Teeth.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: The Farthell there? What’s i’th’ Farthell?
Wherefore that Box?

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Sir, there lyes ſuch Secrets in this Farthell and
Box, which none muſt know but the King, and which hee
ſhall know within this houre, if I may come to th’ ſpeech
of him.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Age, thou haſt loſt thy labour.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Why Sir?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: The King is not at the Pallace, he is gone aboord
a new Ship, to purge Melancholy, and ayre himſelfe: for
if thou bee’ſt capable of things ſerious, thou muſt know
the King is full of griefe.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: So ’tis ſaid (Sir:) about his Sonne, that ſhould
haue marryed a Shepheards Daughter.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: If that Shepheard be not in hand-faſt, let him
ﬂye; the Curſes he ſhall haue, the Tortures he ſhall feele,
will breake the back of Man, the heart of Monſter.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Thinke you ſo, Sir?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Not hee alone ſhall ſuffer what Wit can make
heauie, and Vengeance bitter; but thoſe that are Iermaine
to him (though remou’d ﬁﬅie times) ſhall all come vnder
the Hang-man: which, though it be great pitty, yet it is
neceſſarie. An old Sheepe-whiſtling Rogue, a Ram-ten-
der, to offer to haue his Daughter come into grace? Some
ſay hee ſhall be ſton’d: but that death is too ſoﬅ for him
(ſay I:) Draw our Throne into a Sheep-Coat? all deaths
are too few, the ſharpeſt too eaſie.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Ha’s the old-man ere a Sonne Sir (dœ you heare)
and’t like you, Sir?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Hee ha’s a Sonne: who ſhall be ﬂayd aliue, then
’noynted ouer with Honey, ſet on the head of a Waſpes
Neſt, then ſtand till he be three quarters and a dram dead:
then recouer’d againe with Aquavite, or ſome other hot
Infuſion: then, raw as he is (and in the hoteſt day Progno-
ſtication proclaymes) ſhall he be ſet againſt a Brick-wall,
(the Sunne looking with a South-ward eye vpon him;
where hee is to behold him, with Flyes blown to death.)
But what talke we of these Traitorly-Raſcals, whoſe mi-
ſeries are to be ſmil’d at, their offences being ſo capitall?
Tell me (for you ſeeme to be honeſt plaine men) what you
haue to the King: being ſomething gently conſider’d, Ile
bring you where he is aboord, tender your perſons to his
preſence, whiſper him in your behalfes; and if it be in
man, beſides the King, to effeƈt your Suites, here is man
ſhall dœ it.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: He ſeemes to be of great authoritie: cloſe with
him, giue him Gold; and though Authoritie be a ſtub-
borne Beare, yet hee is oﬅ led by the Noſe with Gold:
ſhew the in-ſide of your Purſe to the out-ſide of his
hand, and no more adœ. Remember ſton’d, and ﬂay’d
aliue.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: And’t pleaſe you (Sir) to vndertake the Buſineſſe
for vs, here is that Gold I haue: Ile make it as much
more, and leaue this young man in pawne, till I bring it
you.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Aﬅer I haue done what I promiſed?

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: I Sir.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Well, giue me the Moitie: Are you a partie in
this Buſineſſe?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: In ſome ſort, Sir: but though my caſe be a pit-
tifull one, I hope I ſhall not be ﬂayd out of it.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Oh, that’s the caſe of the Shepheards Sonne:
hang him, hee’le be made an example.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Comfort, good comfort: We muſt to the King,
and ſhew our ſtrange ſights: he muſt know ’tis none of
your Daughter, nor my Siſter: wee are gone elſe. Sir, I
will giue you as much as this old man do’s, when the Bu-
ſineſſe is performed, and remaine (as he ſayes) your pawne
till it be brought you.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I will truſt you. Walke before toward the Sea-
ſide, gœ on the right hand, I will but looke vpon the
Hedge, and follow you.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: We are bleſs’d, in this man: as I may ſay, euen
bleſs’d.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Let’s before, as he bids vs: he was prouided to
dœ vs good.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: If I had a mind to be honeſt, I ſee Fortune would
not ſuffer mee: ſhee drops Booties in my mouth. I am
courted now with a double occaſion: (Gold, and a means
to dœ the Prince my Maſter good; which, who knowes
how that may turne backe to my aduancement?) I will
bring theſe two Moales, theſe blind-ones, aboord him: if
he thinke it ﬁt to ſhoare them againe, and that the Com-
plaint they haue to the King, concernes him nothing, let
him call me Rogue, for being ſo farre ofﬁcious, for I am
proofe againſt that Title, and what ſhame elſe belongs
to’t: To him will I preſent them, there may be matter in
it.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Leontes, Cleomines, Dion, Paulina, Seruants: Florizel, Perdita.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Sir, you haue done enough, and haue perform’d
A Saint-like Sorrow: No fault could you make,
Which you haue not redeem’d; indeed pay’d downe
More penitence, then done treſpas: At the laſt
Dœ, as the Heauens haue done; forget your euill,
With them, forgiue your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Whileſt I remember
Her, and her Vertues, I cannot forget
My blemiſhes in them, and ſo ſtill thinke of
The wrong I did my ſelfe: which was ſo much,
That Heire-leſſe it hath made my Kingdome, and
Deſtroy’d the ſweet’ſt Companion, that ere man
Bred his hopes out of, true.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Too true (my Lord:)
If one by one, you wedded all the World,
Or from the All that are, tooke ſomething good,
To make a perfeƈt Woman; ſhe you kill’d,
Would be vnparallell’d.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: I thinke ſo. Kill’d?
She I kill’d? I did ſo: but thou ſtrik’ſt me
Sorely, to ſay I did: it is as bitter
Vpon thy Tongue, as in my Thought. Now, good now,
Say ſo but ſeldome.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Not at all, good Lady:
You might haue ſpoken a thouſand things, that would
Haue done the time more beneﬁt, and grac’d
Your kindneſſe better.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: You are one of thoſe
Would haue him wed againe.

speech.speaker: Dio.
speech.line: If you would not ſo,
You pitty not the State, nor the Remembrance
Of his moſt Soueraigne Name: Conſider little,
What Dangers, by his Highneſſe faile of Iſſue,
May drop vpon his Kingdome, and deuoure
Incertaine lookers on. What were more holy,
Then to reioyce the former Queene is well?
What holyer, then for Royalties repayre,
For preſent comfort, and for future good,
To bleſſe the Bed of Maieſtie againe
With a ſweet Fellow to’t?

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: There is none worthy,
(Reſpeƈting her that’s gone:) beſides the Gods
Will haue fulﬁll’d their ſecret purpoſes:
For ha’s not the Diuine Apollo ſaid?
Is’t not the tenor of his Oracle,
That King Leontes ſhall not haue an Heire,
Till his loſt Child be found? Which, that it ſhall,
Is all as monſtrous to our humane reaſon,
As my Antigonus to breake his Graue,
And come againe to me: who, on my life,
Did periſh with the Infant. ’Tis your councell,
My Lord ſhould to the Heauens be contrary,
Oppoſe againſt their wills. Care not for Iſſue,
The Crowne will ﬁnd an Heire. Great Alexander
Leﬅ his to th’ Worthieſt: ſo his Succeſſor
Was like to be the beſt.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Good Paulina,
Who haſt the memorie of Hermione
I know in honor: O, that euer I
Had ſquar’d me to thy councell: then, euen now,
I might haue look’d vpon my Queenes full eyes,
Haue taken Treaſure from her Lippes.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: And leﬅ them
More rich, for what they yeelded.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Thou ſpeak’ſt truth:
No more ſuch Wiues, therefore no Wife: one worſe,
And better vs’d, would make her Sainted Spirit
Againe poſſeſſe her Corps, and on this Stage
(Where we Offendors now appeare) Soule-vext,
And begin, why to me?

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Had ſhe ſuch power,
She had iuſt ſuch cauſe.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: She had, and would incenſe me
To murther her I marryed.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: I ſhould ſo:
Were I the Ghoſt that walk’d, Il’d bid you marke
Her eye, and tell me for what dull part in’t
You choſe her: then Il’d ſhrieke, that euen your eares
Should riﬅ to heare me, and the words that follow’d,
Should be, Remember mine.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Starres, Starres,
And all eyes elſe, dead coales: feare thou no Wife;
Ile haue no Wife, Paulina.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Will you ſweare
Neuer to marry, but by my free leaue?

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Neuer (Paulina) ſo be bleſs’d my Spirit.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Then good my Lords, beare witneſſe to his Oath.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: You tempt him ouer-much.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Vnleſſe another,
As like Hermione, as is her Piƈture,
Affront his eye.

speech.speaker: Cleo.
speech.line: Good Madame, I haue done.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Yet if my Lord will marry: if you will, Sir;
No remedie but you will: Giue me the Ofﬁce
To chuſe you a Queene: ſhe ſhall not be ſo young
As was your former, but ſhe ſhall be ſuch
As (walk’d your ﬁrſt Queenes Ghoſt) it ſhould take ioy
To ſee her in your armes.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: My true Paulina,
We ſhall not marry, till thou bidſt vs.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: That
Shall be when your ﬁrſt Queene’s againe in breath:
Neuer till then.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: One that giues out himſelfe Prince Florizell,
Sonne of Polixenes, with his Princeſſe (ſhe
The faireſt I haue yet beheld) deſires acceſſe
To your high preſence.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: What with him? he comes not
Like to his Fathers Greatneſſe: his approach
(So out of circumſtance, and ſuddaine) tells vs,
’Tis not a Viſitation fram’d, but forc’d
By need, and accident. What Trayne?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: But few,
And thoſe but meane.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: His Princeſſe (ſay you) with him?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I: the moſt peereleſſe peece of Earth, I thinke,
That ere the Sunne ſhone bright on.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Oh Hermione,
As euery preſent Time doth boaſt it ſelfe
Aboue a better, gone; ſo muſt thy Graue
Giue way to what’s ſeene now. Sir, you your ſelfe
Haue ſaid, and writ ſo; but your writing now
Is colder then that Theame: ſhe had not beene,
Nor was not to be equall’d, thus your Verſe
Flow’d with her Beautie once; ’tis ſhrewdly ebb’d,
To ſay you haue ſeene a better.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Pardon, Madame:
The one, I haue almoſt forgot (your pardon:)
The other, when ſhe ha’s obtayn’d your Eye,
Will haue your Tongue too. This is a Creature,
Would ſhe begin a Seƈt, might quench the zeale
Of all Profeſſors elſe; make Proſelytes
Of who ſhe but bid follow.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: How? not women?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Women will loue her, that ſhe is a Woman
More worth then any Man: Men, that ſhe is
The rareſt of all Women.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Gœ Cleomines,
Your ſelfe (aſſiſted with your honor’d Friends)
Bring them to our embracement. Still ’tis ſtrange,
He thus ſhould ſteale vpon vs.Exit.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Had our Prince
(Iewell of Children) ſeene this houre, he had payr’d
Well with this Lord; there was not full a moneth
Betweene their births.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: ’Prethee no more; ceaſe: thou know’ſt
He dyes to me againe, when talk’d-of: ſure
When I ſhall ſee this Gentleman, thy ſpeeches
Will bring me to conſider that, which may
Vnfurniſh me of Reaſon. They are come.
speech.stagedir: Enter Florizell, Perdita, Cleomines, and others.
speech.line: Your Mother was moſt true to Wedlock, Prince,
For ſhe did print your Royall Father off,
Conceiuing you. Were I but twentie one,
Your Fathers Image is ſo hit in you,
(His very ayre) that I ſhould call you Brother,
As I did him, and ſpeake of ſomething wildly
By vs perform’d before. Moſt dearely welcome,
And your faire Princeſſe (Goddeſſe) oh: alas,
I loſt a couple, that ’twixt Heauen and Earth
Might thus haue ſtood, begetting wonder, as
You (gracious Couple) dœ: and then I loſt
(All mine owne Folly) the Societie,
Amitie too of your braue Father, whom
(Though bearing Miſerie) I deſire my life
Once more to looke on him.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: By his command
Haue I here touch’d Sicilia, and from him
Giue you all greetings, that a King (at friend)
Can ſend his Brother: and but Inﬁrmitie
(Which waits vpon worne times) hath ſomething ſeiz’d
His wiſh’d Abilitie, he had himſelfe
The Lands and Waters, ’twixt your Throne and his,
Meaſur’d, to looke vpon you; whom he loues
(He bad me ſay ſo) more then all the Scepters,
And thoſe that beare them, liuing.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Oh my Brother,
(Good Gentleman) the wrongs I haue done thee, ſtirre
Afreſh within me: and theſe thy ofﬁces
(So rarely kind) are as Interpreters
Of my behind-hand ſlackneſſe. Welcome hither,
As is the Spring to th’ Earth. And hath he too
Expos’d this Paragon to th’ fearefull vſage
(At leaſt vngentle) of the dreadfull Neptune,
To greet a man, not worth her paines; much leſſe,
Th’ aduenture of her perſon?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Good my Lord,
She came from Libia.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Where the Warlike Smalus,
That Noble honor’d Lord, is fear’d, and lou’d?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Moſt Royall Sir,
From thence: from him, whoſe Daughter
His Teares proclaym’d his parting with her: thence
(A proſperous South-wind friendly) we haue croſs’d,
To execute the Charge my Father gaue me,
For viſiting your Highneſſe: My beſt Traine
I haue from your Sicilian Shores diſmiſs’d;
Who for Bohemia bend, to ſigniﬁe
Not onely my ſucceſſe in Libia (Sir)
But my arriuall, and my Wifes, in ſafetie
Here, where we are.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: The bleſſed Gods
Purge all Infeƈtion from our Ayre, whileﬁt you
Dœ Clymate here: you haue a holy Father,
A graceful Gentleman, againſt whoſe perſon
(So ſacred as it is) I haue done ſinne,
For which, the Heauens (taking angry note)
Haue leﬅ me Iſſue-leſſe: and your Father’s bleſs’d
(As he from Heauen merits it) with you,
Worthy his goodneſſe. What might I haue been,
Might I a Sonne and Daughter now haue look’d on,
Such goodly things as you?

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Moſt Noble Sir,
That which I ſhall report, will beare no credit,
Were not the proofe ſo nigh. Pleaſe you (great Sir)
Bohemia greets you from himſelfe, by me:
Deſires you to attach his Sonne, who ha’s
(His Dignitie, and Dutie both caſt off)
Fled from his Father, from his Hopes, and with
A Shepheards Daughter.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Where’s Bohemia? ſpeake:

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Here, in your Citie: I now came from him.
I ſpeake amazedly, and it becomes
My meruaile, and my Meſſage. To your Court
Whiles he was haſtning (in the Chaſe, it ſeemes,
Of this faire Couple) meetes he on the way
The Father of this ſeeming Lady, and
Her Brother, hauing both their Countrey quitted,
With this young Prince.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Camillo ha’s betray’d me;
Whoſe honor, and whoſe honeſtie till now,
Endur’d all Weathers.

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Lay’t ſo to his charge:
He’s with the King your Father.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Who? Camillo?

speech.speaker: Lord.
speech.line: Camillo (Sir:) I ſpake with him: who now
Ha’s theſe poore men in queſtion. Neuer ſaw I
Wretches ſo quake: they kneele, they kiſſe the Earth;
Forſweare themſelues as oﬅen as they ſpeake:
Bohemia ſtops his eares, and threatens them
With diuers deaths, in death.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: Oh my poore Father:
The Heauen ſets Spyes vpon vs, will not haue
Our Contraƈt celebrated.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: You are marryed?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: We are not (Sir) nor are we like to be:
The Starres (I ſee) will kiſſe the Valleyes ﬁrſt:
The oddes for high and low’s alike.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: My Lord,
Is this the Daughter of a King?

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: She is,
When once ſhe is my Wife.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: That once (I ſee) by your good Fathers ſpeed,
Will come-on very ſlowly. I am ſorry
(Moſt ſorry) you haue broken from his liking,
Where you were ty’d in dutie: and as ſorry,
Your Choiſe is not ſo rich in Worth, as Beautie,
That you might well enioy her.

speech.speaker: Flo.
speech.line: Deare, looke vp:
Though Fortune, viſible an Enemie,
Should chaſe vs, with my Father; powre no iot
Hath ſhe to change our Loues. Beſeech you (Sir)
Remember, ſince you ow’d no more to Time
Then I dœ now: with thought of ſuch Affeƈtions,
Step forth mine Aduocate: at your requeſt,
My Father will graunt precious things, as Triﬂes.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Would he dœ ſo, I’ld beg your precious Miſtris,
Which he counts but a Triﬂe.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Sir (my Liege)
Your eye hath too much youth in’t: not a moneth
’Fore your Queene dy’d, ſhe was more worth ſuch gazes,
Then what you looke on now.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: I thought of her,
Euen in theſe Lookes I made. But your Petition
Is yet vn-anſwer’d: I will to your Father:
Your Honor not o’re-throwne by your deſires,
I am friend to them, and you: Vpon which Errand
I now gœ toward him: therefore follow me,
And marke what way I make: Come good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Beſeech you (Sir) were you preſent at this Re-
lation?

speech.speaker: Gent.1.
speech.line: I was by at the opening of the Farthell, heard
the old Shepheard deliuer the manner how he found it:
Whereupon (aﬅer a little amazedneſſe) we were all com-
manded out of the Chamber: onely this (me thought) I
heard the Shepheard ſay, he found the Child.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I would moſt gladly know the iſſue of it.

speech.speaker: Gent.1.
speech.line: I make a broken deliuerie of the Buſineſſe;
but the changes I perceiued in the King, and Camillo, were
very Notes of admiration: they ſeem’d almoſt, with ſta-
ring on one another, to teare the Caſes of their Eyes.
There was ſpeech in their dumbneſſe, Language in their
very geſture: they look’d as they had heard of a World
ranſom’d, or one deſtroyed: a notable paſſion of Won-
der appeared in them: but the wiſeſt beholder, that knew
no more but ſeeing, could not ſay, if th’ importance were
Ioy, or Sorrow; but in the extremitie of the one, it muſt
needs be. Enter another Gentleman.
Here comes a Gentleman, that happily knowes more:
The Newes, Rogero.

speech.speaker: Gent.2.
speech.line: Nothing but Bon-ﬁres: the Oracle is fulﬁll’d:
the Kings Daughter is found: ſuch a deale of wonder is
broken out within this houre, that Ballad-makers cannot
be able to expreſſe it. Enter another Gentleman.
Here comes the Lady Paulina’s Steward, hee can deliuer
you more. How gœs it now (Sir.) This Newes (which
is call’d true) is ſo like an old Tale, that the veritie of it is
in ſtrong ſuſpition: Ha’s the King found his Heire?

speech.speaker: Gent.3.
speech.line: Moſt true, if euer Truth were pregnant by
Circumſtance: That which you heare, you’le ſweare
you ſee, there is ſuch vnitie in the proofes. The Mantle
of Queene Hermiones: her Iewell about the Neck of it:
the Letters of Antigonus found with it, which they know
to be his Charaƈter: the Maieſtie of the Creature, in re-
ſemblance of the Mother: the Affeƈtion of Nobleneſſe,
which Nature ſhewes aboue her Breeding, and many o-
ther Euidences, proclayme her, with all certaintie, to be
the Kings Daughter. Did you ſee the meeting of the
two Kings?

speech.speaker: Gent.2.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Gent.3.
speech.line: Then haue you loſt a Sight which was to bee
ſeene, cannot bee ſpoken of. There might you haue be-
held one Ioy crowne another, ſo and in ſuch manner, that
it ſeem’d Sorrow wept to take leaue of them: for their
Ioy waded in teares. There was caſting vp of Eyes, hol-
ding vp of Hands, with Countenance of ſuch diſtraƈtion,
that they were to be knowne by Garment, not by Fauor.
Our King being ready to leape out of himſelfe, for ioy of
his found Daughter; as if that Ioy were now become a
Loſſe, cryes, Oh, thy Mother, thy Mother: then askes
Bohemia forgiueneſſe, then embraces his Sonne-in-Law:
then againe worryes he his Daughter, with clipping her.
Now he thanks the old Shepheard (which ſtands by, like
a Weather-bitten Conduit, of many Kings Reignes.) I
neuer heard of ſuch another Encounter; which lames Re-
port to follow it, and vndo’s deſcription to dœ it.

speech.speaker: Gent.2.
speech.line: What, ’pray you, became of Antigonus, that
carryed hence the Child?

speech.speaker: Gent.3.
speech.line: Like an old Tale ſtill, which will haue matter
to rehearſe, though Credit be aſleepe, and not an eare o-
pen; he was torne to pieces with a Beare: This auouches
the Shepheards Sonne; who ha’s not onely his Innocence
(which ſeemes much) to iuſtiﬁe him, but a Hand-kerchief
and Rings of his, that Paulina knowes.

speech.speaker: Gent.1.
speech.line: What became of his Barke, and his Fol-
lowers?

speech.speaker: Gent.3.
speech.line: Wrackt the ſame inſtant of their Maſters
death, and in the view of the Shepheard: ſo that all the
Inſtruments which ayded to expoſe the Child, were euen
then loſt, when it was found. But oh the Noble Combat,
that ’twixt Ioy and Sorrow was fought in Paulina. Shee
had one Eye declin’d for the loſſe of her Husband, ano-
ther eleuated, that the Oracle was fulﬁll’d: Shee liﬅed the
Princeſſe from the Earth, and ſo locks her in embracing,
as if ſhee would pin her to her heart, that ſhee might no
more be in danger of looſing.

speech.speaker: Gent.1.
speech.line: The Dignitie of this Aƈt was worth the au-
dience of Kings and Princes, for by ſuch was it aƈted.

speech.speaker: Gent.3.
speech.line: One of the prettyeſt touches of all, and that
which angl’d for mine Eyes (caught the Water, though
not the Fiſh) was, when at the Relation of the Queenes
death (with the manner how ſhee came to’t, brauely con-
feſs’d, and lamented by the King) how attentiueneſſe
wounded his Daughter, till (from one ſigne of dolour to
another) ſhee did (with an Alas) I would faine ſay, bleed
Teares; for I am ſure, my heart wept blood. Who was
moſt Marble, there changed colour: ſome ſwownded, all
ſorrowed: if all the World could haue ſeen’t, the Wœ
had beene vniuerſall.

speech.speaker: Gent.1.
speech.line: Are they returned to the Court?

speech.speaker: Gent.3.
speech.line: No: The Princeſſe hearing of her Mothers
Statue (which is in the keeping of Paulina) a Peece many
yeeres in doing, and now newly perform’d, by that rare
Italian Maſter, Iulio Romano, who (had he himſelfe Eter-
nitie, and could put Breath into his Worke) would be-
guile Nature of her Cuſtome, ſo perfeƈtly he is her Ape:
He ſo neere to Hermione, hath done Hermione, that they
ſay one would ſpeake to her, and ſtand in hope of anſwer.
Thither (with all greedineſſe of affeƈtion) are they gone,
and there they intend to Sup.

speech.speaker: Gent.2.
speech.line: I thought ſhe had ſome great matter there in
hand, for ſhee hath priuately, twice or thrice a day, euer
ſince the death of Hermione, viſited that remoued Houſe.
Shall wee thither, and with our companie peece the Re-
ioycing?

speech.speaker: Gent.1.
speech.line: Who would be thence, that ha’s the beneﬁt
of Acceſſe? euery winke of an Eye, ſome new Grace
will be borne: our Abſence makes vs vnthriﬅie to our
Knowledge. Let’s along.Exit.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: Now (had I not the daſh of my former life in
me) would Preferment drop on my head. I brought the
old man and his Sonne aboord the Prince; told him, I
heard them talke of a Farthell, and I know not what: but
he at that time ouer-fond of the Shepheards Daughter (ſo
he then tooke her to be) who began to be much Sea-ſick,
and himſelfe little better, extremitie of Weather conti-
nuing, this Myſterie remained vndiſcouer’d. But ’tis all
one to me: for had I beene the ﬁnder-out of this Secret,
it would not haue relliſh’d among my other diſcredits.
Here come thoſe I haue done good to againſt my will,
and alreadie appearing in the bloſſomes of their For-
tune.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: Come Boy, I am paſt mœ Children: but thy
Sonnes and Daughters will be all Gentlemen borne.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: You are well met (Sir:) you deny’d to ﬁght
with mee this other day, becauſe I was no Gentleman
borne. See you theſe Clothes? ſay you ſee them not,
and thinke me ſtill no Gentleman borne: You were beſt
ſay theſe Robes are not Gentlemen borne. Giue me the
Lye: dœ: and try whether I am not now a Gentleman
borne.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I know you are now (Sir) a Gentleman borne.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: I, and haue been ſo any time theſe foure houres.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: And ſo haue I, Boy.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: So you haue: but I was a Gentleman borne be-
fore my Father: for the Kings Sonne tooke me by the
hand, and call’d mee Brother: and then the two Kings
call’d my Father Brother: and then the Prince (my Bro-
ther) and the Princeſſe (my Siſter) call’d my Father, Father;
and ſo wee wept: and there was the ﬁrſt Gentleman-like
teares that euer we ſhed.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: We may liue (Sonne) to ſhed many more.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: I: or elſe ’twere hard luck, being in ſo prepoſte-
rous eſtate as we are.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I humbly beſeech you (Sir) to pardon me all the
faults I haue committed to your Worſhip, and to giue
me your good report to the Prince my Maſter.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: ’Prethee Sonne dœ: for we muſt be gentle, now
we are Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Thou wilt amend thy life?

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I, and it like your good Worſhip.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Giue me thy hand: I will ſweare to the Prince,
thou art as honeſt a true Fellow as any is in Bohemia.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: You may ſay it, but not ſweare it.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Not ſweare it, now I am a Gentleman? Let
Boores and Francklins ſay it, Ile ſweare it.

speech.speaker: Shep.
speech.line: How if it be falſe (Sonne?)

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: If it be ne’re ſo falſe, a true Gentleman may
ſweare it, in the behalfe of his Friend: And Ile ſweare to
the Prince, thou art a tall Fellow of thy hands, and that
thou wilt not be drunke: but I know thou art no tall Fel-
low of thy hands, and that thou wilt be drunke: but Ile
ſweare it, and I would thou would’ſt be a tall Fellow of
thy hands.

speech.speaker: Aut.
speech.line: I will proue ſo (Sir) to my power.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: I, by any meanes proue a tall Fellow: if I do not
wonder, how thou dar’ſt venture to be drunke, not being
a tall Fellow, truſt me not. Harke, the Kings and Prin-
ces (our Kindred) are going to ſee the Queenes Piƈture.
Come, follow vs: wee’le be thy good Maſters.Exeunt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Leontes, Polixenes, Florizell, Perdita, Camillo, Paulina: Hermione (like a Statue:) Lords, & c.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: O graue and good Paulina, the great comfort
That I haue had of thee?

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: What (Soueraigne Sir)
I did not well, I meant well: all my Seruices
You haue pay’d home. But that you haue vouchſaf’d
(With your Crown’d Brother, and theſe your contraƈted
Heires of your Kingdomes) my poore Houſe to viſit;
It is a ſurplus of your Grace, which neuer
My life may laſt to anſwere.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: O Paulina,
We honor you with trouble: but we came
To ſee the Statue of our Queene. Your Gallerie
Haue we paſs’d through, not without much content
In many ſingularities; but we ſaw not
That which my Daughter came to looke vpon,
The Statue of her Mother.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: As ſhe liu’d peereleſſe,
So her dead likeneſſe I dœ well beleeue
Excells what euer yet you look’d vpon,
Or hand of Man hath done: therefore I keepe it
Louely, apart. But here it is: prepare
To ſee the Life as liuely mock’d, as euer
Still Sleepe mock’d Death: behold, and ſay ’tis well.
I like your ſilence, it the more ſhewes-off
Your wonder: but yet ſpeake, ﬁrſt you (my Liege)
Comes it not ſomething neere?

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Her naturall Poſture.
Chide me (deare Stone) that I may ſay indeed
Thou art Hermione; or rather, thou art ſhe,
In thy not chiding: for ſhe was as tender
As Infancie, and Grace. But yet (Paulina)
Hermione was not ſo much wrinckled, nothing
So aged as this ſeemes.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Oh, not by much.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: So much the more our Caruers excellence,
Which lets gœ-by ſome ſixteene yeeres, and makes her
As ſhe liu’d now.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: As now ſhe might haue done,
So much to my good comfort, as it is
Now piercing to my Soule. Oh, thus ſhe ſtood,
Euen with ſuch Life of Maieſtie (warme Life,
As now it coldly ſtands) when ﬁrſt I woo’d her.
I am aſham’d: Do’s not the Stone rebuke me,
For being more Stone then it? Oh Royall Peece:
There’s Magick in thy Maieſtie, which ha’s
My Euils coniur’d to remembrance; and
From thy admiring Daughter tooke the Spirits,
Standing like Stone with thee.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: And giue me leaue,
And dœ not ſay ’tis Superſtition, that
I kneele, and then implore her Bleſſing. Lady,
Deere Queene, that ended when I but began,
Giue me that hand of yours, to kiſſe.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: O, patience:
The Statue is but newly ﬁx’d; the Colour’s
Not dry.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: My Lord, your Sorrow was too ſore lay’d-on,
Which ſixteene Winters cannot blow away,
So many Summers dry: ſcarce any Ioy
Did euer ſo long liue; no Sorrow,
But kill’d it ſelfe much ſooner.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: Deere my Brother,
Let him, that was the cauſe of this, haue powre
To take-off ſo much griefe from you, as he
Will peece vp in himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Indeed my Lord,
If I had thought the ſight of my poore Image
Would thus haue wrought you (for the Stone is mine)
Il’d not haue ſhew’d it.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Dœ not draw the Curtaine.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: No longer ſhall you gaze on’t, leaſt your Fancie
May thinke anon, it moues.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Let be, let be:
Would I were dead, but that me thinkes alreadie.
(What was he that did make it?) See (my Lord)
Would you not deeme it breath’d? and that thoſe veines
Did verily beare blood?

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: ’Maſterly done:
The very Life ſeemes warme vpon her Lippe.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: The ﬁxure of her Eye ha’s motion in’t,
As we are mock’d with Art.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Ile draw the Curtaine:
My Lord’s almoſt ſo farre tranſported, that
Hee’le thinke anon it liues.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Oh ſweet Paulina,
Make me to thinke ſo twentie yeeres together:
No ſetled Sences of the World can match
The pleaſure of that madneſſe. Let’t alone.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: I am ſorry (Sir) I haue thus farre ſtir’d you: but
I could afﬂiƈt you farther.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Dœ Paulina:
For this Afﬂiƈtion ha’s a taſte as ſweet
As any Cordiall comfort. Still me thinkes
There is an ayre comes from her. What ﬁne Chizzell
Could euer yet cut breath? Let no man mock me,
For I will kiſſe her.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Good my Lord, forbeare:
The ruddineſſe vpon her Lippe, is wet:
You’le marre it, if you kiſſe it; ſtayne your owne
With Oyly Painting: ſhall I draw the Curtaine.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: No: not theſe twentie yeeres.

speech.speaker: Perd.
speech.line: So long could I
Stand-by, a looker-on.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Either forbeare,
Quit preſently the Chappell, or reſolue you
For more amazement: if you can behold it,
Ile make the Statue moue indeed; deſcend,
And take you by the hand: but then you’le thinke
(Which I proteſt againſt) I am aſſiſted
By wicked Powers.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: What you can make her dœ,
I am content to looke on: what to ſpeake,
I am content to heare: for ’tis as eaſie
To make her ſpeake, as moue.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: It is requir’d
You dœ awake your Faith: then, all ſtand ſtill:
On: thoſe that thinke it is vnlawfull Buſineſſe
I am about, let them depart.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Proceed:
No foot ſhall ſtirre.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: Muſick; awake her: Strike:
’Tis time: deſcend: be Stone no more: approach:
Strike all that looke vpon with meruaile: Come:
Ile ﬁll your Graue vp: ſtirre: nay, come away:
Bequeath to Death your numneſſe: (for from him,
Deare Life redeemes you) you perceiue ſhe ſtirres:
Start not: her Aƈtions ſhall be holy, as
You heare my Spell is lawfull: dœ not ſhun her,
Vntill you ſee her dye againe; for then
You kill her double: Nay, preſent your Hand:
When ſhe was young, you woo’d her: now, in age,
Is ſhe become the Suitor?

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: Oh, ſhe’s warme:
If this be Magick, let it be an Art
Lawfull as Eating.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: She embraces him.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: She hangs about his necke,
If ſhe pertaine to life, let her ſpeake too.

speech.speaker: Pol.
speech.line: I, and make it manifeſt where ſhe ha’s liu’d,
Or how ſtolne from the dead?

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: That ſhe is liuing,
Were it but told you, ſhould be hooted at
Like an old Tale: but it appeares ſhe liues,
Though yet ſhe ſpeake not. Marke a little while:
Pleaſe you to interpoſe (faire Madam) kneele,
And pray your Mothers bleſſing: turne good Lady,
Our Perdita is found.

speech.speaker: Her.
speech.line: You Gods looke downe,
And from your ſacred Viols poure your graces
Vpon my daughters head: Tell me (mine owne)
Where haſt thou bin preſeru’d? Where liu’d? How found
Thy Fathers Court? For thou ſhalt heare that I
Knowing by Paulina, that the Oracle
Gaue hope thou waſt in being, haue preſeru’d
My ſelfe, to ſee the yſſue.

speech.speaker: Paul.
speech.line: There’s time enough for that,
Leaſt they deſire (vpon this puſh) to trouble
Your ioyes, with like Relation. Go together
You precious winners all: your exultation
Partake to euery one: I (an old Turtle)
Will wing me to ſome wither’d bough, and there
My Mate (that’s neuer to be found againe)
Lament, till I am loſt.

speech.speaker: Leo.
speech.line: O peace Paulina:
Thou ſhouldſt a husband take by my conſent,
As I by thine a Wife. This is a Match,
And made betweene’s by Vowes. Thou haſt found mine,
But how, is to be queſtion’d: for I ſaw her
(As I thought) dead: and haue (in vaine) ſaid many
A prayer vpon her graue. Ile not ſeeke farre
(For him, I partly know his minde) to ﬁnde thee
An honourable husband. Come Camillo,
And take her by the hand: whoſe worth, and honeſty
Is richly noted: and heere iuſtiﬁed
By Vs, a paire of Kings. Let’s from this place.
What? looke vpon my Brother: both your pardons,
That ere I put betweene your holy lookes
My ill ſuſpition: This your Son-in-law,
And Sonne vnto the King, whom heauens direƈting
Is troth-plight to your daughter. Good Paulina,
Leade vs from hence, where we may leyſurely
Each one demand, and anſwere to his part
Perform’d in this wide gap of Time, ſince ﬁrſt
We were diſſeuer’d: Haſtily lead away.Exeunt.

personae.persona: Perdita, Daughter to Leontes and Hermione.
Old Shepheard, reputed Father of Perdita.
Other Lords, and Gentlemen, and Seruants.
